unit_title: Magnetic Force on Current-Carrying Wires: Force on Current Elements in Magnetic Fields
subject: AP Physics C: Electricity & Magnetism
expanded_description: This unit extends the concept of magnetic force from individual moving charges to current-carrying conductors, developing the fundamental relationship F = IL × B and its applications to practical devices. Students will learn to calculate forces on straight and curved wires, analyze torque on current loops, and apply these principles to electric motors and other electromagnetic systems.
learning_objectives: Calculate magnetic force on straight current-carrying wires
Apply the right-hand rule for force direction on current elements
Determine net force and torque on current loops in magnetic fields
Analyze forces on curved wires and non-uniform current distributions
Solve problems involving current-carrying conductors in complex field configurations
Apply magnetic force principles to electric motors and measuring instruments
prerequisites: Understanding of magnetic force on moving charges (Lorentz force)
Knowledge of current as moving charges
Experience with torque and rotational dynamics

core_concept.principle: Magnetic Force on Current Elements, F = IL × B, Torque on Current Loops, Motor Principle, Force Integration
core_concept.explanation: Current-carrying wires experience magnetic forces due to the motion of charge carriers within them. The fundamental relationship F = IL × B describes the force on a straight wire segment, while more complex geometries require integration of force elements. These principles form the basis for electric motors, galvanometers, and numerous other electromagnetic devices.

sections.introduction: This section develops the fundamental force relationship for straight current-carrying wires and applies it to various geometric configurations and practical situations.

key_concept.definition: F = IL × B, Right-Hand Rule, Force Magnitude, Force Direction, Current Element
key_concept.context: The magnetic force on a straight current-carrying conductor results from the cumulative effect of Lorentz forces on all moving charges within the wire. For a straight wire segment of length L carrying current I in uniform magnetic field B, the net force is given by the vector cross product F = IL × B, where L is a vector pointing in the direction of current flow with magnitude equal to the wire length.

classifications.value: Classification based on wire orientation and field geometry
characteristics: Perpendicular configuration: maximum force, F = ILB
Multiple segments: vector sum of forces
Non-uniform fields: force varies along wire
Three-dimensional arrangements: full vector analysis required
classifications.behavior: Different orientations produce different force magnitudes and directions. Perpendicular wires experience maximum force. Parallel wires experience zero net force. Angled wires have reduced force proportional to sinθ. Multiple wire segments require vector addition. Non-uniform fields necessitate integration. 3D configurations require careful component analysis.

classifications.note: The direction of the L vector is defined as the direction of conventional current flow (positive to negative), opposite to electron flow direction

principles.statement: Force on Straight Wire: F = I(L × B) where L is vector along current direction. Magnitude: F = ILBsinθ where θ is angle between L and B. Right-Hand Rule: Point fingers in current direction, curl toward B field, thumb shows force direction. Force Derivation: From Lorentz force: dF = nAq(v_d × B)dl, with I = nAqv_d, gives dF = I(dl × B). Integration: For straight wire in uniform B: F = I∫(dl × B) = I(L × B). Current Direction: Conventional current (positive to negative) defines L direction. Multiple Wires: Net force = vector sum of forces on all segments. Special Cases: L ∥ B → F = 0. L ⊥ B → F_max = ILB. Force Properties: Force is perpendicular to both current direction and magnetic field. Force does no work (always perpendicular to motion). Force on stationary current-carrying wire is zero (needs moving charges).
principles.application: Calculate force magnitude and direction on straight wires. Determine wire orientation for maximum/minimum force. Solve for unknown currents from measured forces. Analyze forces in multi-wire systems. Design electromagnetic systems using force principles. Calculate wire accelerations from magnetic forces.
principles.example: Wire carrying 5 A, 0.5 m long, perpendicular to 0.8 T field: F = 2 N. If angled at 30°, F = 1 N. If parallel, F = 0.
principles.analogy: The magnetic force on a current-carrying wire is like 'water flowing through a hose in a crosswind'. The 'current' is like the 'water flow', the 'magnetic field' is like the 'crosswind', and the resulting 'force on the hose' is perpendicular to both the 'water flow' and the 'wind direction'. If you 'point the hose with the wind' (parallel), no push. If you 'point the hose across the wind' (perpendicular), maximum push. The 'right-hand rule' is like determining which way the hose would be 'pushed sideways' by the 'combination of water flow and wind'.

worked_examples.title: Basic Wire Force Calculation
worked_examples.problem: A straight wire 0.40 m long carries 8.0 A current directed along the positive x-axis. It lies in a uniform magnetic field B = (0.30 j + 0.40 k) T. Find the magnetic force on the wire.

step_by_step.explanation: L = 0.40 i m (points in current direction), I = 8.0 A, B = (0.30 j + 0.40 k) T
Right-hand rule: current in +x, B has +y and +z components, force should have -y and +z components ✓

worked_examples.final_answer: F = (-1.28 j + 0.96 k) N, magnitude = 1.60 N. Force lies in yz-plane perpendicular to both current and field.
worked_examples.concept_applied: Vector calculation of magnetic force on straight wire

image.caption: Force calculation on straight wire in 3D field

worked_examples.title: Right-Angle Wire Configuration
worked_examples.problem: A wire bent at 90° carries 6.0 A current and has 0.30 m segments along x and y axes. It lies in a uniform magnetic field B = 0.50 k T. Find the net magnetic force on the wire.

step_by_step.explanation: F_net = F_x + F_y = 0.90 i - 0.90 j N
Force at 45° in xy-plane, perpendicular to effective current direction

worked_examples.final_answer: Net force F = (0.90 i - 0.90 j) N, magnitude 1.27 N. The bent wire experiences a single net force, not a torque.
worked_examples.concept_applied: Net force calculation on bent wire

worked_examples.title: Force Balance Measurement
worked_examples.problem: A straight horizontal wire 0.25 m long carries current and experiences a magnetic force that balances its weight. The wire has mass 4.0 g and is in a horizontal 0.80 T magnetic field perpendicular to the wire. Find the required current.

step_by_step.explanation: Weight = mg = 0.0040 kg × 9.8 m/s² = 0.0392 N downward
For balance, magnetic force must equal weight: F_mag = 0.0392 N upward
F = ILB (perpendicular, so sinθ = 1), so I = F/(LB)
For upward force with horizontal B field perpendicular to wire, current direction depends on orientation

worked_examples.final_answer: Required current = 0.196 A. The direction must be such that F = IL × B points upward.

sections.section_title: 2. Torque on Current Loops and Applications
sections.introduction: This section explores the torque experienced by current-carrying loops in magnetic fields, developing the fundamental principles behind electric motors, galvanometers, and other electromagnetic devices.

key_concept.definition: Magnetic Torque, Current Loop, Magnetic Moment, Motor Principle, Galvanometer Operation
key_concept.context: Current-carrying loops experience torque in magnetic fields due to the differential forces on opposite sides of the loop. This torque tends to align the loop's magnetic moment with the external field. The relationship τ = μ × B, where μ is the magnetic moment, forms the operational basis for electric motors, measuring instruments, and numerous electromagnetic devices.

image.caption: Torque on current loops and magnetic moment alignment

classifications.value: Classification based on loop geometry and orientation
classifications.behavior: Different loop geometries exhibit characteristic torque behaviors. Rectangular loops have calculable forces on straight segments. Circular loops require integration but have simple results. Multi-turn coils multiply the effective current. Solenoids behave like magnetic dipoles. Arbitrary shapes require numerical methods. Coupled loops have interdependent torques.

examples.explanation: Current loops experiencing torque that causes continuous rotation
Current measurement using torque on suspended coil

classifications.note: The magnetic moment μ of a current loop points perpendicular to the loop plane according to the right-hand rule (curl fingers in current direction, thumb shows μ direction)

principles.statement: Magnetic Moment Definition: μ = NIA for planar loop, where N = number of turns, I = current, A = area vector (magnitude = area, direction = normal to plane by right-hand rule). Torque on Loop: τ = μ × B. Magnitude: τ = μBsinθ where θ is angle between μ and B. Torque Derivation: For rectangular loop: forces on sides parallel to axis create torque couple. τ = 2F(a/2)sinθ = IabBsinθ = IABsinθ. Maximum Torque: Occurs when μ ⊥ B (θ = 90°). Zero Torque: When μ ∥ B (θ = 0° or 180°) - equilibrium positions. Stable Equilibrium: μ ∥ B in same direction. Unstable Equilibrium: μ ∥ B in opposite directions. Work and Energy: Potential energy U = -μ·B = -μBcosθ. Work to rotate: W = μB(cosθ₁ - cosθ₂). Applications: Electric motors: continuous rotation via commutator. Galvanometers: current measurement via angular deflection. MRI: detection of nuclear magnetic moments. Compass needles: alignment with Earth's magnetic field.
principles.application: Calculate torque on current loops of various shapes. Determine equilibrium orientations of magnetic moments. Analyze electric motor operation principles. Design galvanometers and current-measuring devices. Solve energy and work problems for rotating loops. Analyze stability of magnetic orientations.
principles.example: Single-turn 0.1 m × 0.2 m rectangular loop, 2 A current, in 0.5 T field: μ = 0.04 A·m², τ_max = 0.02 N·m. Multi-turn coil: proportional increase in μ and τ.
principles.analogy: A current loop in a magnetic field is like a 'compass needle' that we can control electrically. The 'magnetic moment' is like the 'strength and direction of the compass magnetization'. The 'torque' is like the 'twisting force' that tries to align the compass with the Earth's field. An 'electric motor' is like continuously 'reversing the compass polarity' just as it aligns, so it keeps chasing the field direction and rotates continuously. A 'galvanometer' is like a 'very sensitive compass' where we measure how much it twists to determine the 'current strength'. The 'potential energy' is like a 'gravitational analogy' - the loop 'wants to fall' into alignment with the field, just like a pendulum wants to hang straight down.

worked_examples.title: Torque on Rectangular Loop
worked_examples.problem: A rectangular loop 0.15 m × 0.25 m carries 3.0 A current and has 50 turns. It is oriented with its plane at 30° to a uniform 0.40 T magnetic field. Calculate the magnetic moment and torque on the coil.

step_by_step.explanation: Plane at 30° to B field means normal is at 60° to B field, so θ = 60°
Torque acts to align μ with B, perpendicular to both vectors

worked_examples.final_answer: Magnetic moment = 5.63 A·m², Torque = 1.95 N·m. The torque tends to rotate the loop to decrease the 60° angle between μ and B.
worked_examples.concept_applied: Torque calculation on multi-turn rectangular loop

worked_examples.title: Circular Loop Analysis
worked_examples.problem: A circular loop of radius 0.12 m carrying 4.0 A current lies in the xy-plane. A uniform magnetic field B = (0.30 i + 0.40 k) T is present. Find the magnetic moment and torque on the loop.

step_by_step.explanation: Loop in xy-plane, current counterclockwise (right-hand rule): μ points in +z direction
μ = IA = 4.0 × 0.04524 = 0.1810 A·m² in z-direction, so μ = 0.181 k A·m²
Torque is in y-direction, tending to rotate the loop around the y-axis

worked_examples.final_answer: Magnetic moment μ = 0.181 k A·m², Torque τ = 0.0543 j N·m. The torque acts to align the loop's normal (z-direction) with the magnetic field.
worked_examples.concept_applied: Vector torque calculation on circular loop

image.caption: Torque on circular current loop in 3D field

worked_examples.title: Galvanometer Design
worked_examples.problem: A galvanometer coil has 100 turns of wire forming a rectangle 2.0 cm × 3.0 cm. The magnetic field in the gap is 0.20 T. What current is needed to produce a torque of 1.5 × 10⁻⁴ N·m when the coil is at its maximum sensitivity position?

step_by_step.explanation: Maximum sensitivity when μ ⊥ B, so sinθ = 1, τ_max = μB

worked_examples.final_answer: Required current = 12.5 mA. This relatively small current produces measurable deflection in the galvanometer.
worked_examples.concept_applied: Galvanometer current calculation from torque requirement

worked_examples.title: Force on Curved Wire
worked_examples.problem: A wire carrying 5.0 A current is bent into a semicircle of radius 0.08 m in the xy-plane. A uniform magnetic field B = 0.25 k T is present. Find the net magnetic force on the wire.

step_by_step.explanation: For uniform B field, net force on any closed current loop is zero. For open curve, F = I(L_eff × B) where L_eff is straight-line vector from start to end points
L_eff = vector from start to end = (-0.16 i + 0 j + 0 k) m
Integration of dF = I(dl × B) over semicircle gives same result

worked_examples.final_answer: Net force F = 0.20 j N. The force is the same as on a straight wire connecting the endpoints.
worked_examples.concept_applied: Force calculation on curved wire in uniform field

common_misconceptions: Thinking magnetic forces can do work on current-carrying wires
Believing net force on a closed current loop in uniform B field is non-zero
Confusing the direction of the L vector in F = IL × B
Thinking torque depends on the shape of the current loop beyond its area
Assuming magnetic moment points in the current direction rather than normal to the loop
Believing the force on a curved wire requires complex integration in uniform fields
Thinking electric motors work by magnetic attraction/repulsion rather than torque
summary: This unit has established the fundamental principles of magnetic forces on current-carrying conductors, from simple straight wires to complex loops and coils. Students have mastered the application of F = IL × B for force calculations and τ = μ × B for torque analysis, developing the theoretical foundation for understanding electric motors, measuring instruments, and numerous electromagnetic devices. The concepts of magnetic moment and its alignment with external fields provide crucial insight into both technological applications and fundamental electromagnetic behavior.
